-e ---

# permuted

# forms of permutation
permutation appears in  
* letters  
* signs  
* syllables  
* components  
* words  
* semantics  


# Semantic permutation

Semantic permutation means two compounds of a word get 'flipped', that is the first compound is suddenly interpreted with the meaning of the second and vice versa. This is especially prevalent in symbolic systems and liturgic languages, and related to [phono-semantic-matching](phono-semantic-matching.html) in [wanderwort](wanderwort.html)s.  

## examples

Medieval Latin foresta probably represents the fusion of two earlier words: one taken as an adaptation of the Late Latin phrase forestis silva (â€œthe outside woodsâ€), mistaking forestis for woods

# component permutation  
## prefix and suffix permutation  
Very common is the permutation of prefix and suffix stems  
See [ma](ma.html) [ge](ge.html) [se](se.html) [to](to.html) -ğƒ  

# Letter and sign permutation

Many words of Egyptian have matches in Semitic and PIE languages if one allows for reverse right-to-left reading of the signs. These are not necessary to assert broad matches in the dictionary and might be due to [chance](chance.html), but since permutation is a proven mechanism of language evolution, and some forms migth factually (but unprovably) be related through permutation, we leave them here. In any case they can serve as mnemonics.  

An extended class is permutation
